title: Cellulitis vs. Necrotizing Infection
diagnosis_topic: Differentiating simple cellulitis from early necrotizing fasciitis
setup_script: “A 50-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a rapidly enlarging area of redness and swelling on her right thigh. She reports severe pain that she describes as much worse than the appearance of the skin would suggest. She has had fevers and malaise over the past day. On exam, the erythematous area extends broadly across the anterior thigh and is exquisitely tender to palpation. How would you proceed with this patient?”

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 125/80 mmHg, HR 102 bpm, RR 20/min, Temp 38 °C.
Erythematous plaque extending 10 cm with indistinct borders; no bullae or crepitus present; severe tenderness out of proportion to exam.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates empiric IV antibiotics
If resident marks the edges of erythema and monitors progression

dynamic_flow.reply: CT scan shows fascial thickening with small foci of gas in the soft tissues.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident calls for emergent surgical evaluation
dynamic_flow.reply: Operative exploration reveals gray, necrotic fascia with dishwater fluid confirming necrotizing fasciitis.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident is asked to describe operative technique
dynamic_flow.reply: Examiner requests details of incision, exposure, identification of viable versus non-viable tissue, extent of debridement, wound management, and plans for return to the operating room.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays consultation thinking it is cellulitis
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient deteriorates into septic shock requiring pressors.
Pain out of proportion, systemic toxicity, rapid progression, and imaging findings support necrotizing infection.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident states cellulitis typically responds to oral antibiotics
dynamic_flow.reply: Correct for cellulitis without systemic features, but not appropriate for this case.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses the LRINEC score
dynamic_flow.reply: A useful risk stratification tool but not a substitute for surgical exploration when suspicion is high.
Patient requires ICU admission, ongoing broad-spectrum antibiotics, and return to the OR for repeat debridements.
Patient remains critically ill with recurrent necrosis and progressive organ dysfunction.
ICU, infectious disease, and surgical teams coordinate ongoing management.

critical_decision_points: Recognizing pain out of proportion as a red flag for necrotizing infection
Using labs and imaging to support diagnosis without delaying surgery
Urgent surgical consultation and operative exploration
Ability to describe operative technique in detail
Postoperative management including repeat debridement and ICU care
